tossups.question: This character undertakes a pilgrimage after his wife claims that the Byzantine Emperor Hugo wears a crown better than he does. Renaud and his three brothers rebel against this character in The Four Sons of Aymon. A dream about a greyhound fighting a bear is one of the visions sent to this man by the Angel Gabriel in another work. This character splits open the head of Baligant, the Emir of Babylon, using his sword (*) Joyeuse ("zhwah-YOOZ"). Legends about this ruler and his Twelve Peers comprise the Matter of France. This ruler's nephew is the protagonist of the most famous example of the chanson de geste, which focuses on the Battle of Roncevaux Pass. For 10 points, name this uncle of the paladin Roland and King of the Franks.
tossups.answer: Charlemagne [or Charles]

tossups.question: Echinocandins target these organisms by inhibiting synthesis of 1,3-beta-glucans. Vitamin D2 is derived from a compound named for being found in these organisms, which were researched by Akira Endo while developing the first statins. Polyenes (poly-eens) and azoles (AY-zoles) are used to treat infections caused by these organisms such as (*) Cryptococcus and Candida albicans, the source of thrush. The immunosuppressants cyclosporin and mycophenolate are named for their discovery in these organisms, as is ergosterol. The first known beta-lactam antibiotic was discovered in a plate containing Staphylococcus and one of these organisms. For 10 points, name this kingdom containing penicillium, a mold, as well as yeasts.
tossups.answer: fungi [antiprompt on molds, mushrooms, or yeasts]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. In the UK, people with this status were the main subjects of the scabies experiments of Kenneth Mellanby, while in the US Ancel Keys forced people with this status into the Minnesota Starvation Experiment. After not being granted this status, Bayard Rustin protested segregated prison dining halls. Since the Seeger decision, US citizens need not be religious to claim this status. The rejection of this status in 1967 led to a prison sentence for (*) boxer Muhammad Ali. In the 1940s, many people with this status joined the Civilian Public Service. In the UK, men with this status were overwhelmingly Quaker. Israel has granted this status to Haredi Jews, exempting them from the IDF. For 10 points, name this status of people who refuse military service.
tossups.answer: conscientious objectors [accept pacifists or non-interventionists or antimilitarists; accept answers like people who refuse to fight in wars before the end; prompt on things like Quakers or Jehovah's Witnesses; prompt on being ineligible for the draft; prompt on draft dodgers or draft avoiders]
tossups.answer_formatted: conscientious objectors [accept pacifists or non-interventionists or antimilitarists; accept answers like people who refuse to fight in wars before the end; prompt on things like Quakers or Jehovah's Witnesses; prompt on being ineligible for the draft; prompt on draft dodgers or draft avoiders]
acceptable: people who refuse to fight in wars before the end

tossups.question: It's not Larry Rivers, but a brown face interrupts the red strip of paint that runs across the top of this artist's abstract interpretation of Emanuel Leutze's (LOITS-uhs) Washington Crossing the Delaware. The Tate now owns a painting by this student of Reginald Marsh that draws from Irv Novick's work for All American Men of War. This artist painted a girl (*) thinking “I don’t care! I’d rather sink than call Brad for help!” In one of this artist's signature paintings, a pilot narrates, "I pressed the fire control... and ahead of me rockets blazed through the sky..." as another plane explodes with the title onomatopoeia. For 10 points, name this American Pop Artist of comic-book-inspired paintings such as Drowning Girl and Whaam!
tossups.answer: Roy Lichtenstein

tossups.question: Due to its high cross section for these particles, BPSG has been phased out of use in integrated circuits. Wigner and Szilard observed that graphite bombarded with these particles would release energy after annealing. The SNS facility at Oak Ridge National Laboratory focuses a pulsed beam at liquid mercury to cause spallation of these particles. Boron-10 is typically used in (*) nuclear reactor control rods to absorb these particles. By bombarding beryllium atoms with alpha particles, James Chadwick was able to prove their existence in 1932. Beta-minus decay results in one of these particles being transformed into a lighter baryon. They contain two down quarks and one up quark. For 10 points, name these uncharged particles which form nuclei with protons.
tossups.answer: neutrons

tossups.question: A composer from this country who often calls for unconventional vocal techniques, such as reverberating the voice through a wine glass in her album Our Lady of Late, included her piece "Earth Seen from Above" in her opera Atlas. Another composer from this country sang, "O Judge, O Mom and Dad" through a vocoder in her experimental performance piece "O Superman." A vocoder was also used to alter Ludwig van Beethoven's Ninth Symphony in a film score composed by a musician from this country who performed the (*) Brandenburg Concertos on a Moog synthesizer for her album Switched-On Bach. Meredith Monk and Laurie Anderson are composers from, for 10 points, what country, in which Wendy Carlos studied at the Columbia-Princeton Electronic Music Center?
tossups.answer: United States of America [or U.S.A.; or America]

tossups.question: During this man's reign, "rope stretching" relieved the tax burden of some farmers granted private ownership rights. Donald Keene's 922-page biography of this ruler draws heavily on his corpus of over 100,000 poems. This non-Hawaiian ruler, who abandoned New Years' rituals and broke beef-eating taboos, took power in a war characterized by bouts of ee ja nai ka dance mania. During this man's rule, the last two of the "big four" (*) zaibatsu firms were formed. This son of Komei was declared "sacred and inviolable" in a constitution that built upon the Charter Oath. He came to power following the Boshin War which effectively ended the samurai class. For 10 points, name this Japanese emperor who lends his name to a 19th century "restoration."
tossups.answer: Meiji Emperor [or Meiji the Great; or Mutsuhito; or Meiji-tennō]

tossups.question: When this character is asked who will "get up and give history a kick up the backside and get it going again," he says "They're called social reformers." This character takes a stack of comic books home for his alcoholic, one-legged father. He corrects another character's pronunciations of "scalar" and "magnitude," which leads them to discuss Charles Darwin as a "man of magnitude." This teenager recalls flying a (*) kite that his adult friend made out of tomato-box wood. The servants Sam and Willie practice ballroom dancing before and after this character comes onstage and mistreats them for being black. For 10 points, name this seventeen-year-old paired with "the boys" in the title of an Athol Fugard play.
tossups.answer: Master Harold [or Hally; accept "Master Harold"...and the boys]

tossups.question: This hero is depicted calling out the number three, the losing throw in a game of dice, in a black-figure vase painting by Exekias. This hero gives a purple sash to a rival and receives a sharp sword in return after an all-day duel ends in a draw. He ignores Calchas' warning to stay in his tent, after which his concubine Tecmessa hides his son Eurysaces (“yoo-ree-SAH-keez”). This hero enters a dispute with the warrior who covers him as he carries the body of (*) Achilles back to camp. In a Sophocles play, he goes mad and kills a herd of sheep before killing himself; that happens after this "gigantic" warrior and king of Salamis loses a contest for the armor of Achilles to Odysseus. For 10 points, name this son of Telamon, "the greater" of two heroes with his name.
tossups.answer: Telamonian Ajax [or Ajax the Greater; or Aias; do not accept any other Ajax]
tossups.answer_formatted: Telamonian Ajax [or Ajax the Greater; or Aias; do not accept "any other Ajax"]

tossups.question: The British Museum houses the oldest known humanoid-depiction of this figure, in which this figure is placed between Brahma and Indra on the Bimaran Casket. Depictions of this figure often include a hair curl between the eyebrows known as an urna along with up to 32 other physical characteristics. The fearlessness of this figure is conveyed by a pose where the (*) palm of the right hand is held towards the viewer. This figure's previous life of luxury is represented by the elongated earlobes seen in images such as the giant carving of him in Leshan. Giant stone statues of this figure carved into the cliffs at Bamyan were destroyed by the Taliban. For 10 points, name this religious leader often depicted meditating under a bodhi tree.
tossups.answer: The Buddha [or Siddhārtha Gautama; or Gautama Buddha; Shakyamuni Buddha; or Varada Buddha]
tossups.answer_formatted: The Buddha [or Siddhārtha Gautama; or Gautama Buddha; Shakyamuni Buddha; or Varada Buddha]

tossups.question: A dictator of this country came to power after leading a coup against the Smallholder's Party and coined the phrase "salami tactics" for removing opposition. This country's army shot at its AVH secret police in a clash over control of a radio building in its capital. Sweden's Raoul Wallenberg worked with Carl Lutz to issue thousands of passports to Jews in this country. At the Melbourne Olympics, this country's (*) water polo team was victorious over a larger one in the Blood in the Water Match. This country was said to be the "happiest barracks" in the Eastern Bloc under the "Goulash Communism" policies instituted following a Warsaw Pact invasion. Janos Kadar was the longtime dictator of, for 10 points, what country where Imre Nagy ("em-ray nahj") led a 1956 uprising from Budapest?
tossups.answer: Hungary [or Magyarország; or Hungarian People's Republic]

tossups.question: In September 1995, sales of this good spiked in Hindu communities worldwide due to its role in an alleged miracle involving murti of Ganesha. During Thaipusam, offerings of this good are often carried by pilgrims of Murugan. Honey, jaggery, this good and two of its derivatives are combined to make panchamrita, a mixture that can be used to (*) bathe murti. The Devas and the Asuras worked together to produce fourteen ratnas from this good, including the Apsaras and the moon. Lakshmi first appeared following that event, during which the poison halahala and nectar amrita were created when the gods churned an immense ocean of this good. For 10 points, name this liquid foodstuff produced by Kamadhenu, a divine cow.
tossups.answer: milk [or ksheer; accept Ocean of Milk or Kshira Sagara]

tossups.question: Selective Availability was turned off prior to this conflict so that civilian-grade Trimpacks could be used. Operation Secret Squirrel began a day before this operation officially started and demonstrated the power of CALCM missiles in the longest-ever flight combat mission. In the leadup to this conflict, the PR firm of Hill & Knowlton secretly hired a woman known only as Nurse Nayirah to give false testimony to Congress. The (*) "Highway of Death" got its name during this conflict, where coalition forces commanded by General Norman Schwarzkopf were responding to the invasion of Kuwait. For 10 points, name this war during the George H. W. Bush administration in which Saddam Hussein's forces were defeated.
tossups.answer: First Gulf War [or Operation Desert Storm; or Operation Desert Shield; or Persian Gulf War; or First Iraq War; prompt on Kuwait War before mentioned; do not accept or prompt on just "Iraq War"; do not accept "Second Gulf War" or "Second Iraq War"]
tossups.answer_formatted: First Gulf War [or Operation Desert Storm; or Operation Desert Shield; or Persian Gulf War; or First Iraq War; prompt on Kuwait War before mentioned; do not accept or prompt on "just "Iraq War"; do not accept "Second Gulf War" or "Second Iraq War"]

tossups.question: A "counter" variant of this process has been used as a response to Max Black's argument using this process to justify itself. Karl Popper rejected this kind of reasoning, claiming more easily falsifiable theories are superior to theories supported by it. The predicates "grue" and "bleen" were used by Nelson Goodman as examples of the "new riddle" of this kind of reasoning. David Hume posed the classic (*) "problem" of this form of reasoning, arguing that it could not demonstrate that the sun would rise tomorrow, even if the sun had been observed to rise every preceding day. For 10 points, name this mode of reasoning that contrasts with deduction.
tossups.answer: induction [or problem of induction; accept word forms like inductive reasoning]
tossups.answer_formatted: induction [or problem of induction; accept word forms like inductive reasoning]

tossups.question: As a teenager, this world leader wrote an epic novel of colonial-era Mexico titled Babylon, Babylon. After graduating, he made his fortune supervising a deal for Nestle to buy Pfizer's baby food division. The CGT organized a months-long transportation strike to oppose this leader's plan to reduce 42 separate pension systems to one. This onetime M&A boss at Rothschild & Company shut down the prestigious ENA civil service school following a "great (*) national debate." Approval ratings for this “Jupiterian” leader dropped following the Benalla ("ben-uh-luh") affair. Protestors angry about a fuel tax hike by this man's government stormed roundabouts during the Yellow Vest protests. For 10 points, name this leader of En Marche who is the President of France.
tossups.answer: Emmanuel Macron [or Emmanuel Jean-Michel Frédéric Macron]

tossups.question: Objects that perform this task experience a rearward shift in their center of pressure and a resulting tuck which must be compensated for. The term "compressibility" is used to explain many of the difficulties associated with completing this task, which coincides with a dependence on temperature and corresponding non-linearity in the measurements from pitot tubes. "The demon in the thin air" is a colloquial name for the loss of (*) control due to wave drag found in many early attempts to complete this task. Doing this task typically requires swept-back wings and was long thought impossible due to a literal wall. For 10 points, name this task which was achieved for the first time in the Bell X-1 by Chuck Yeager and produces a loud boom.
tossups.answer: breaking the sound barrier [or going Mach 1; accept going supersonic; prompt on going very fast; prompt on creating a sonic boom before "loud boom"; do not accept or prompt on “flying”]
tossups.answer_formatted: breaking the sound barrier [or going Mach 1; accept going supersonic; prompt on going very fast; prompt on creating a sonic boom before "loud boom; do not accept or prompt on "“flying”"]

tossups.question: During this novel's prologue, the protagonist and Hooper discuss that, while they do not know what they are walking towards, it is not "the real thing." In this novel's first chapter, another character calls his father a "social leper" during a car ride. Anthony Blanche interrupts an art show put on by this novel's protagonist, who paints Latin American ruins. That protagonist of this novel befriends an alcoholic with an attachment to a (*) teddy bear named Aloysius. A character in this novel works in a monastery in Tunisia years after the protagonist has an affair with his sister Julia, whom he met at the title estate. For 10 points, name this novel about Charles Ryder's relationship with Sebastian Flyte and his family, by Evelyn Waugh.
tossups.answer: Brideshead Revisited

tossups.question: A charged class of these structures is typically formed from the sulfonylated ("sul-fone-eel-ated") fluoropolymer Nafion and covered in a platinum catalyst. Examples of these structures made from ionomers exploit the Donnan effect to serve as proton conductors in a class of fuel cells which operate at roughly room temperature. Large numbers of hollow fibers made of these structures comprise most modern dialyzers ("dia-ly-zers"). The force required to prevent movement through these structures is denoted (*) pi and scales directly with the van 't Hoff factor. The overall direction of movement through these structures is determined by the tonicity. Osmosis is defined as movement through, for 10 points, what structures, which only allow molecules below a certain size to pass?
tossups.answer: semi-permeable membranes [or partially permeable membranes; or differentially permeable membranes; accept proton-exchange membranes; prompt on artificial membranes, cell membranes, or filters with "what property do they have?"; prompt on proton conductors before mentioned]
tossups.answer_formatted: semi-permeable membranes [or partially permeable membranes; or differentially permeable membranes; accept proton-exchange membranes; prompt on artificial membranes, cell membranes, or filters with "what property do they have?; prompt on proton conductors before mentioned]
promptable: filters with "what property do they have?

tossups.question: A certain novel's 42nd chapter, which is titled for this property, contains a lengthy sentence that celebrates this property for "imparting some special virtue of its own, as in ... japonicas" while at the same time noting it "strikes more of panic to the soul than that redness which affrights in blood." A "vague, nameless horror" is created by this property possessed by a creature who is discussed at nine meetings called "gams." A gold (*) doubloon is offered to whoever first spots a character with this color by a man who employs Daggoo and Flask. That same title character with this color is pursued by Starbuck and Queequeg. For 10 points, name this color of the sperm whale pursued by Captain Ahab in Moby-Dick.
tossups.answer: the whiteness of the whale [or the whiteness of Moby Dick; accept white; prompt on the skin color or appearance of Moby Dick]
tossups.answer_formatted: the whiteness of the whale [or the whiteness of Moby Dick; accept white; prompt on the skin color or appearance of Moby Dick]

tossups.question: Medical researchers often use the Randall-Selitto test to measure this phenomenon in animals, while this phenomenon can be measured in "dols" on the Hardy-Wolff-Goodell scale in humans. It's not stress, but a 2016 paper by Hoffman et al found that physicians widely under-prescribed medicines to counteract this phenomenon in African Americans. "Radiating" is an option on Ronald Melzack's McGill Questionnaire to quantify this phenomenon. This "fifth (*) vital sign" is often assessed on a 0 to 10 scale. Cicely Saunders advocated treating the "total" version of this phenomenon in palliative care by using opioids. For 10 points, name this "physiological and emotional response to a noxious stimulus" that you might experience by stubbing your toe.
tossups.answer: pain [or chronic pain; or physical pain; accept pain threshold; accept pain tolerance; prompt on suffering]
tossups.answer_formatted: pain [or chronic pain; or physical pain; accept pain threshold; accept pain tolerance; prompt on suffering]

tossups.question: After being asking whether he believes the Pope is the Antichrist by an Anabaptist named James, this character responds, "Whether he is or not, I still have nothing to eat." This character, who got his name by combining "rather sound judgment with great simplicity of mind," has dinner with King Charles Edward and five other deposed kings. The Manichaean pessimist Martin accompanies this title character, who finds red (*) sheep adorned with gold after leaving El Dorado. This character acknowledges that "we must cultivate our garden" after seeing the ugliness of Baron Thunder-ten-Tronckh's daughter and rejecting Doctor Pangloss's Leibnizian philosophy. Cunegonde is the love interest of, for 10 points, what title character of a novella by Voltaire?
tossups.answer: Candide

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about some environmental catastrophes that led to the creation of the EPA.
parts: A 1952 issue of Time magazine declared that this river "oozes rather than flows" through Cleveland. It infamously caught on fire in 1969.

26 million fish were killed in this state in 1969 due to pollution from food processing plants. The Marjorie Harris Carr Greenway in this state runs along some of the route of a cancelled cross-state canal.
Sports fans in this New England city still sing "Dirty Water," a song by The Standells partially inspired by the pollution in the Charles River.

bonuses.leadin: In a poem by this author, a soldier says that having girls is better than having boys, since you can expect weddings for daughters while sons will be buried in the grass. For 10 points each:
answers: Du Fu [or Tu Fu; or Zimei; accept Du Shaoling; accept Du Gongbu; accept Shaoling Yelao]
"Song of the Wagons" [or such translations as "Song of the War Chariots" and "Ballad of the Army Carts"; accept "bīng chē xíng"]
parts: Name this Chinese poet who wrote “Thinking of Li Bai at the End of the Sky.”
The An Lushan rebellion inspired this Du Fu poem, which opens with whinnying horses and the rumbling title objects covering a bridge in the dust they stir up.
Du Fu, who died in 770 CE, wrote during this dynasty. Li Bai also wrote during this dynasty, considered the Golden Age of Chinese poetry.
answers_formatted: Du Fu [or Tu Fu; or Zimei; accept Du Shaoling; accept Du Gongbu; accept Shaoling Yelao]
"Song of the Wagons" [or such translations as "Song of the War Chariots" and "Ballad of the Army Carts; accept bīng chē xíng]

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about voicing in music theory, for 10 points each:
answers: inversion [or inverted chords; accept first inversion]
augmented sixth [accept Italian, French, or German sixth]
parts: Voicing often refers to the orientation of notes in one of these musical configurations, which are sets of notes heard simultaneously. These entities can comprise progressions that drive harmonic development.
This term is used to describe chords whose lowest note is not the root note. For example, a C major chord in the "first" variant of this term uses E as its lowest note instead of C.

When voicing chords, the doubling of notes must be performed deliberately. For example, when voicing augmented chords of this numerical interval –– variants of which are called Italian, French, and German –– the interval’s notes should not be doubled, but the tonic pitch should be.

bonuses.leadin: Lobsters do not die of old age; they die from other processes such as disease or starvation. For 10 points each:
parts: A lobster's longevity may come from their production of this enzyme that repairs the end of chromosomes.
Turritopsis dohrnii is an "immortal" type of this cnidarian because it can continually cycle from polyp to medusa and back. Some "box" species of this animal have a particularly venomous sting.
Biologically immortal organisms must be able to avoid this phenomenon in which cell division ceases. The replicative form of this phenomenon occurs at the Hayflick limit.

bonuses.leadin: The author of this book, despite donating all profits to charity, was issued an eleven-million-dollar Swiss tax bill due to a legal mess up. For 10 points each:
answers: x-rays film [accept x-radiation; prompt on radiation or imaging]
parts: Name this non-fiction book that traces the title system from 1918 until a thaw in 1956. This book describes the typical life of a zek.
This Soviet intelligence agency, whose name means Committee for State Security, was ordered to assassinate Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn with ricin to prevent him from finishing the Gulag Archipelago.
The Gulag Archipelago circulated as underground samizdat. Samizdat music records were often published on film intended for use with this technology, invented by Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen.

bonuses.leadin: Hall P. Beck alleged that this person, "one of the best developed youngsters" at the Harriet Lane Home, suffered from hydrocephalus. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this subject who was classically conditioned to develop a phobia of furry, white objects.

John B. Watson built on the fame from the Little Albert experiment to get a lucrative gig in the ad industry. This critic argued that advertisers were using subliminal messaging to manipulate the public in his 1957 book The Hidden Persuaders.
Watson's Kerplunk experiment was named for the sound rats made when one of these structures was shortened. Tyron's Rat Experiment examined how quickly rats could complete one of these puzzles.

bonuses.leadin: Deformation mechanism maps can be used to identify the temperature at which this process changes from the Nabarro-Herring regime to the Coble regime. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this plastic deformation caused by prolonged loading.

The general equation governing creep relates strain rate to this function of the quantity activation energy over RT. Other phenomena modeled with this function include capacitor discharge and radioactive decay.
Coble and Nabarro-Herring creep both occur via solid-state forms of this process. This process's associated constant equals mobility times k-sub-B times T by the Einstein-Smoluchowski relation.

bonuses.leadin: Part of this novel is based on the author getting fired for writing about made-up animals like the Sulphur-Bellied Whale for a scientific magazine. For 10 points each:
answers: The Good Soldier Svejk [or The Good Soldier Svejk: And His Fortunes in the World War; or The Fateful Adventures of the Good Soldier Svejk During the World War; or Osudy dobrého vojáka Švejka za světové války]
parts: Name this unfinished satirical novel whose title character is arrested by a secret policeman after discussing flies defecating on a portrait of Emperor Franz Joseph I.
The Good Soldier Svejk was written in this language. Milan Kundera wrote The Unbearable Lightness of Being in this language, although he now writes in French.
Before joining the army, Svejk earned his living by stealing these creatures. One of these creatures is transformed into Poligraf Poligrafovich in a Mikhail Bulgakov novel.
answers_formatted: The Good Soldier Svejk [or The Good Soldier Svejk: And His Fortunes in the World War; or The Fateful Adventures of the Good Soldier Svejk During the World War; or Osudy dobrého vojáka Švejka za světové války]
acceptable: The Good Soldier Svejk: And His Fortunes in the World War
The Fateful Adventures of the Good Soldier Svejk During the World War

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about wide-sweeping works of history.
parts: Anand Giridharadas ("gih-rih-dar-uh-DOSS") argued that historians should stop writing "from the viewpoint of 30,000 feet" in a review of this man's most recent work, Upheaval. This man is best-known for Guns, Germs and Steel.
This Israeli historian's Sapiens starts with the Cognitive Revolution which "kick-started history 70,000 years ago" and extends to the Scientific Revolution.

Bill Bryson, who wrote a book titled A Short History of Nearly Everything, wrote a travelogue of this country titled In a Sunburned Country. Thomas Kenneally's The Commonwealth of Thieves is a history of this one-time convict colony.

bonuses.leadin: African-American soprano Angel Blue headlined a Grammy Award-winning 2019 Met revival of this opera. For 10 points each:
answers: Price [accept Mary Violet Leontyne Price; accept Florence Beatrice Price]
parts: Name this opera, which includes characters such as the pianist Jasbo Brown, the honey merchant Peter, and a drug dealer who sings "It Ain't Necessarily So."
Blue's interpretation of this Porgy and Bess aria, which declares that "the livin' is easy" during its title season, has been hailed for its unique musical embellishments.

Blue has been compared to the Met's first African-American prima donna, who had this last name. A Black woman composer with this married surname premiered her pioneering First Symphony in Chicago in 1933.
answers_formatted: Price [accept Mary Violet Leontyne Price; accept Florence Beatrice Price]

bonuses.leadin: Søren Sørensen introduced the use of this letter in one context in 1909; since then, there have been countless folk etymologies. For 10 points each:
answers: p [accept potential, power, Potenz, puissance, pouvoir, potentia, or pondus; prompt on, but do not reveal, pH]
H+ ("H plus") [or the hydrogen cation; accept hydrogen one plus, hydrons or protons; prompt on pH]
parts: Name this letter which was chosen to refer to a specific electrode, unless it was chosen to mean a word in German, or one in French, or one in Latin. This letter indicates the use of the cologarithm function with base 10.
By far the most common use of p in chemistry is to represent the number of these ions in solution, which quantifies how acidic something is.
Though often studied as a precursor to the Lewis concept, this acid-base theory that focuses on the donation of H+ was developed in the same year.

bonuses.leadin: A poetry collection named for this place and intended for performance with jazz accompaniment was inspired by a phrase from Henry Miller's Into the Night Life. For 10 points each:
answers: Coney Island [accept A Coney Island of the Mind]
parts: Name this New York location that titles a collection featuring the poems "Junkman's Obbligato" and "I am Waiting."
This author's time in Mexico City inspired his poem "Mexico City Blues." Dean abandons Sal Paradise in Mexico City in this author's novel On the Road.
Allen Ginsberg's brief stay in this mental institution inspired a repeated line that tells Carl Solomon "I'm with you" in this place in the poem "Howl."
answers_formatted: Coney Island [accept A Coney Island of the Mind]
acceptable: A Coney Island of the Mind

bonuses.leadin: This denomination's current president, J.D. Greear, has said that Black Lives Matter is a "gospel issue." For 10 points each:
answers: Southern Baptist Convention [or SBC; prompt on Baptists]
parts: Name this denomination founded in 1845 in opposition to anti-slavery efforts by other members of the Triennial Convention.
In this epistle, Paul declares that he is sending back Onesimus ("o-NEH-sih-muhs"), who is "no longer a slave, but something beyond a slave," with instructions to welcome Onesimus as himself.

This patriarch's curse on Ham's son Canaan, erroneously called the "Curse of Ham," has been used by some Christians to justify white supremacy and the enslavement of Black people. This prophet and his family survived the Flood.

bonuses.leadin: Identify the following about the career of Belle Moskowitz, for 10 points each:
parts: "Mrs. M" was a close behind-the-scenes advisor to this Governor of New York. This man, nicknamed the “Happy Warrior,” opposed prohibition before leading the company that built the Empire State Building.

Lewis Hine, who was hired by Moskowitz to photograph illegal dance houses, photographed these people working in the Carolinas. Before it was outlawed, these people were used as mine trappers because of their small size.

Moskowitz began her career working at the Educational Alliance, one of these places for Jewish immigrants. The first American woman to win the Nobel Peace Prize founded the most prominent one of these places in the US.

bonuses.leadin: As of 2019, the Boston MFA is the only museum to have a curator specifically devoted to investigating this property of their artworks. For 10 points each:
answers: Metropolitan Museum of Art [or The Met]
parts: Identify this term from art history that traces the history of previous owners of a work of art.
This New York museum ended its exhibition Nedjemankh ("neh-jeh-MANK”) and His Gilded Coffin due to false provenance records. This largest US art museum displays a reconstructed Temple of Dendur.

Andre Breton questioned the provenance of this artist’s painting of a sleeping Romani woman after it was purchased by Alfred Barr for the MOMA. In that work, this artist painted a lion passing by an exhausted woman under the moonlight.

bonuses.leadin: In two dimensions this algorithm can construct a Voronoi diagram. For 10 points each:
answers: k-nearest neighbors algorithm [accept k-nearest neighbors classification or k-nearest neighbors regression; accept k-NN in place of "k-nearest neighbors"]
weighted [or weighting; accept weighted average or weighted arithmetic mean]
logistic [or logit; accept logistic regression or logistic curve; accept logistic function; do not accept or prompt on "log" or "logarithmic"]
parts: Name this classification algorithm where nearby points in the training set vote on an input's classification.

This type of voting scheme can compensate for skew in k-NN by making some votes worth more. Similarly, this type of average may give your tests greater importance than other scores when calculating your math grade.

This adjective describes a regression technique that assumes the log-odds of an event and its predictor variables are linearly related. This type of function is given by the equation (read slowly) one over the quantity one plus e to the negative x.
answers_formatted: k-nearest neighbors algorithm [accept k-nearest neighbors classification or k-nearest neighbors regression; accept k-NN in place of "k-nearest neighbors]
logistic [or logit; accept logistic regression or logistic curve; accept logistic function; do not accept or prompt on "log" or "logarithmic"]

bonuses.leadin: The remains of an indigenous rebel leader from this modern-day country named Guaicaipuro ("gwie-kie-POOR-oh”) were symbolically placed in its National Pantheon in 2001. For 10 points each:
answers: Hugo Chavez [or Hugo Rafael Chávez Frías]
parts: Identify this oil-producing country, the birthplace of revolutionary "precursor" Francisco de Miranda.
This Venezuelan president revived the cult of Guaicaipuro. His "Bolivarian Revolution" has proven less successful under his successor, Nicolas Maduro.

Venezuela, like Uruguay and Peru, has a far-left political party named for this man, born José Gabriel Condorcanqui ("con-dor-CAN-kee”), who led a failed revolt against the Spanish in the 1780s. This man took his name from the last Incan ruler.

bonuses.leadin: In a novel by this author, Eleanor Bold must choose between Mr. Arabin, Bertie Stanhope, and the scheming Low Church advocate Mr. Slope. For 10 points each:
answers: warden of Hiram's Hospital [accept The Warden]
parts: Name this author who included his novel Barchester Towers in his Barsetshire series.
Barchester Towers opens in the aftermath of Septimus Harding having resigned this lucrative position at Hiram's Hospital. This post titles the first novel in the Barsetshire series.
Trollope befriended this author while writing his Barsetshire series, later going on to write a biography of him. This author wrote about the mischievous Becky Sharp in his novel Vanity Fair.

bonuses.leadin: This man once threatened to fire any member of the Tonkünstler Society who didn't attend his annual Christmas benefit. For 10 points each:
answers: Cupertino [or Copertino] (the saint is Joseph of Cupertino, also the patron saint of astronauts)
parts: Name this man who kills his younger rival in an Alexander Pushkin play and narrates his story from a mental asylum in a Milos Forman film.

Salieri is described as the "patron saint of mediocrities" in Forman's Amadeus. The closest real saint may be Joseph, a patron saint of poor students who hails from this city. Another city of this name is Apple's California headquarters.
Amadeus playwright Peter Shaffer also wrote Equus, a play about a young man obsessed with one of these creatures, which come in varieties such as thoroughbreds.
metadata: the saint is Joseph of Cupertino, also the patron saint of astronauts

bonuses.leadin: During this figure's childhood, the Kouretes shouted and struck their shields with their spears while dancing to cover the sound of his crying. For 10 points each:
answers: hanging in the air [or hanging from a tree; accept equivalents mentioning hanging or being suspended midair]
parts: Name this god. Rhea gave Cronus a stone to swallow instead of this god, who later defeated Cronus to become king of the gods.
Since Cronus ruled sea, sky, and land, Zeus' cradle was hidden in this manner to avoid Cronus' detection. A description is fine.
Zeus spent his childhood in a cave on a Cretan mountain with this name. Zeus abducted Ganymede from a mountain of this name near Troy.
answers_formatted: hanging in the air [or hanging from a tree; accept equivalents mentioning hanging or being suspended midair]

bonuses.leadin: Eric Fischl created a controversial nude statue to commemorate this man in a stadium named for him in New York. For 10 points each:
answers: Arthur Ashe [or Arthur Robert Ashe Jr.]
parts: Identify this first Black man to win the US Open and Wimbledon. He died of AIDS in 1993.

Ashe called a press conference to announce he had AIDS to pre-empt a story by this newspaper. This "McPaper" achieved a circulation of over 5 million by the late 1980s, making it Gannett's best-selling paper.
After much debate, a statue of Ashe was erected on Monument Avenue in this city, Ashe's hometown. J.E.B. Stuart's statue was removed from this capital of the Confederacy in 2020.
